English:
The book tells the story of the two transits of Venus that took place in 1761 and 1769. The book begins with Halley making a call to scientists almost 50 years before the first transit. He predicts when the phenomenon will occur, the best points of observation calls on scientists to undertake and urge the scientists to take part in a world effort to observe the phenomenon. Accurate observations can provide important information such as the Earth-Sun distance and the size of the solar system. Throughout the book we see why some countries choose to participate, how they selected their astronomers (and information about their lives) and the success stories and frustrations of the expeditions.
